did.langmaterial: The material is in English and Spanish
did.abstract: The records of the Casa de Unidad Cultural Arts and Media Center cover the organization’s efforts to promote, develop, and celebrate Hispanic and Latino arts and traditions in Southwest Detroit. The record group consists primarily of correspondence, board minutes, grant proposals and reports, newsletters, event and program budgets, event flyers, educational workshop reports and audio material.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The record group was donated June 2009 by CLAVE, the Community of Latino Artists, Visionaries, and Educators (donor no. 10201).

accruals.p: No further additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is not held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Casa de Unidad records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Casa de Unidad Cultural Arts and Media Center was founded in December of 1980. In November of 1981, the organization was officially incorporated by the State of Michigan. Throughout the 1980s, 1990s, and early 2000s, the center devoted its resources to identifying, developing and preserving the Hispanic/Latino cultural heritage of Southwest Detroit. Among the programs offered by Casa de Unidad were educational workshops in the visual, literary, and performing arts. The center also sponsored a workshop designed especially for high school students entitled Tradiciones Vivas.

Besides cultivating local interest in the arts, the center nurtured many local artists by providing an exhibition space in the Galería, the center's art gallery. Casa de Unidad also complied the first Michigan Hispanic Arts Directory in 1988-1989. Moreover, the center held an annual two-day performing arts festival called Unity in the Community, which brought together local businesses, human service agencies, artists and entertainers for a weekend of cultural unity and celebration.

One of Casa de Unidad's most significant contributions to the preservation of local cultural history came out of their 1987 documentation project, which resulted in the published study Tradiciones del Pueblo: Traditions of Three Mexican Feast Days in Southwest Detroit (1990). The study was based on a series of oral histories and interviews from Detroit Latinos about the community's artistic and cultural traditions, such as Posadas, Fiestas Gaudalupanas, and Día de los Muertos.

scopecontent.p: The records of Casa de Unidad cover the period between 1980 and 2006. The collection consists primarily of correspondence, board minutes, grant proposals and reports, newsletters, event and program budgets, event flyers, educational workshop reports and audio material. The majority of the material is in English, though a small number of flyers, newsletters, and audio recordings are in Spanish. The collection contains the following series: Administrative Material, Educational/Artistic Activities, Unity in the Community Festival, and Audio Material.

Administrative Material series documents Casa de Unidad's history, organizational structure, expenses and contributions. The series contains written accounts of the organization's history, its mission statement, and its by-laws and constitution. The series also contains the organization's financial statements and budgets, board minutes, grant proposals and reports, as well as multiple volumes from Casa de Unidad's bilingual newsletter "El Barrio."

did.unittitle: Michigan Council for the Arts, correspondence and reports 1982-1995
Neighborhood Opportunity Fund, correspondence and reports 2000-2006
City of Detroit Planning and Development Department 1993-2001
Presbyterian Sisters of Charity, funding proposals 1983
Campaign for Human Development, funding proposal 1981-1983
Report on Community Development Block Grant 1986-1988
Hispanos Unidos and Casa de Unidad Lease 1982-1984

scopecontent.p: Educational/Artistic Activities series reflects Casa de Unidad's commitment to promoting, developing and celebrating Hispanic and Latino arts in Southwest Detroit. The series is separated into four subseries: Tradiciones Vivas, Workshops, Other Activities, and Artist Files.

Subseries Tradiciones Vivas contains material related to Casa de Unidad's art and humanities workshop for high school students. The subseries includes the workshop's budget, outgoing correspondence, program evaluations, and photographs.

Subseries Workshops documents the diverse offering of extracurricular programs offered by Casa de Unidad. The material in the Workshops subseries includes project reports from each class meeting as well as workshop syllabi.

did.unittitle: Printing Workshop by the Human Press undated

scopecontent.p: Subseries Other Activities underscores the organization's significant contribution to the cultural development of the Detroit Latino community. Much of the material in the subseries is event announcements and flyers, with the majority related to exhibits from the Galería, the center's art gallery. However, the subseries also contains the Michigan Hispanic Arts Directory of 1988-1989, 1989-1990, and 1990-1993. The 1988-1989 Hispanic Art Directory was the first of its kind complied in Michigan. Also included in the subseries is Tradiciones del Pueblo, a published study based on a series of oral histories and interviews from Detroit Latinos about the community's artistic and cultural traditions.

did.unittitle: Tradiciones del Pueblo: Traditions of Three Mexican Feast Days in Southwest Detroit, 1990
"La onda Latina en Poesia," poetry anthology 1985

scopecontent.p: Subseries Artist Files contains files kept by Casa de Unidad on a variety of Michigan based artists. Many of the artists on file exhibited their work at the organization's Galería. The material is arranged alphabetically according to the artists' name, and primarily contains the artist's resume, biographical material, and flyers from upcoming exhibitions or events.

Unity in the Community Festival series contains material from Casa de Unidad's annual two-day festival celebrating the cultural diversity of Southwest Detroit and showcasing the commercial districts and human service agencies in the community. The series contains correspondence with various local community organizations, event budgets and corporate grants/sponsorship, and publicity material such as newspaper clippings and flyers.

Audio Material series contains 31 cassette tapes. Cassette tapes 1 through 10 are a part of Casa de Unidad's efforts to document the cultural legacy of the Detroit Latino community through a series of oral histories and interviews with individuals who settled in Detroit during the 1920s. Other recordings include lectures presented at Casa de Unidad, recordings of cultural events, and board meetings.
